bio.p: Ana Tostões, PhD, is chair of DOCOMOMO International and associate professor of architecture at IST-Technical University of Lisbon. She has been published widely. In 2006, she was awarded the title of Commander of the Order of Infante dom Henrique.

Ana Braga holds a master's degree in architecture from the Instituto Superior Técnico (IST), Lisbon. She worked as an architect in Lisbon at MC Arquitectos and Teresa Nunes da Ponte and, in 2013, collaborated with Exchanging World's Visions research project as a research fellow.

abstract.p: The article focuses on the role of the “Survey on Regional Architecture in Portugal” in 1955 and its effects on contemporary Portuguese architecture. A photographic survey organizes and indexes a group of buildings with precise criteria, allowing a general panorama. In fact these built-environment, large-scale archives play an important role in heritage preservation. In the 1930s, an interesting phenomenon gathered architects who, although committed to the modern movement and enthusiasts of industrial progress, showed a growing interest in vernacular buildings and settlements. Some of these architects became photographers, attentive to a pre-industrial world that was endangered, to record timeless architecture and expose new aesthetic values. This interest generated several movements centered on an appreciation of regional architecture. Along with nostalgia, there stood out the feeling that there were still many lessons to be drawn from these threatened vernacular structures.

Lúcio Costa's “founder” text, “Documentação necessária,” rescued some ideas of the 1929 text “O Aleijadinho e a arquitectura tradicional,” in which Lúcio “looked at his works from the standpoint of pure architecture” trying to understand what he designated the homogeneity of the Portuguese colonization-period civil architecture “way to make.” “Our architecture is robust, strong, massive, and all he ever did was slim, delicate, and fine. Our architecture is calm and quiet, and everything he did was tortured and nervous. Everything about it is stable, severe, simple, and never pedantic. As for him, everything is unstable, rich, complicated, and a little precious.” See Costa ,“Documentação necessária,” 86–94; see also Costa ,“O Aleijadinho e a arquitectura tradicional,”in Lúcio Costa: sobre Arquitectura , ed. In fact, during the survey period, architects gradually changed their attitude from earlier rejection of the question of the Casa Portuguesa to subsequent rejection of instrumentalized modernism as it had been envisaged across other countries, whether in the rest of Europe or on the east coast of the United States. While Távora's intellectual transformation might be characterized as a retreat by the younger generation of Portuguese architects, it will no doubt prove in years to come a culturally consistent insight into the failures of modernity. Lima Bastos was the initial coordinator, followed by Henrique Castro Caldas. This survey focused mainly on the squalor and poor living conditions of the people and comprised eighty case studies. The book had a huge international impact with examples of vernacular from all over the world, namely the vegetal roof of a Minka house by Futagawa. Yukio Futagawa (1932–2013) is a well-known photographer. His work comprises photographs of modern architecture and also of vernacular and traditional architecture. In the1950s, he published a ten-volume photographic book of Japanese traditional houses. In the1970s, he also produced photos of wooden houses in Europe, houses in Northern Europe, and houses in Southern Europe.

Richard Neutra possessed the first edition of Arquitectura Popular em Portugal at his Silver Lake house, in Los Angeles and became, at the time, honorary member of Portuguese Architects' Chamber.
